page.title: 11THE FREE MINERS
page.content: The traditional rights and privileges of the Free Miners were protected in 1946 by the Coal Industry Nationalisation Act. A miner has to be born within the Hundred of St. Briavels, to be over 21 years of age and to have worked for at least a year and a day in a coal or iron mine within its boundaries to qualify to become a Free Miner. He then has the right to claim from the crown a place to work for his own profit in either coal or iron ore within the Hundred. There are still a few Free Miners working in this way today. It is common to hear foresters addressing their friends as "O but".This is a legacy of coalmining days when your workmate was your "butty".You relied on each other for your safety and livelihood.
